newsitem.title: ROMANIA: Romania software dealers join hands against piracy.
newsitem.headline: Romania software dealers join hands against piracy.

text.p: The Romanian representative office of U.S. software giant Microsoft Corp has teamed up with other local dealers to wage war on software piracy in the ex-communist country, a company official said on Monday.
"Software piracy in Romania has reached some of the highest rates in the world," Silviu Hotaran, head of Microsoft Romania, told Reuters.

Microsoft delayed opening an office in Romania until last December because the cojuntry lacks copyright protection although the 23 million inhabitants make it Eastern Europe's second largest market after Poland.
U.S. officials say some 93 percent of the local computer software market is counterfeit, while fake music tapes, compact discs and videotapes still dominate the local market.
Bogus liquor, cigarettes and coffee are also common.
Microsoft's Romanian office and other local software dealers set up a unit of the Business Software Alliance (BSA) last week to protect the sector's interests against piracy.

"The BSA has no legal weapons to fight piracy on its own," said Constanta Moisescu, head of the Romanian Copyright Office the chief anti-piracy watchdog. "They can report counterfeiting cases to us, so that we can take the cases to court."

"We deal with copyright breaches in all sectors, but we can only act when software or other copyright holders alert us to acts of piracy," said Moisescu, whose understaffed office is also fighting against budget constraints.
"The piracy figures are less important. What really matters is to have the new copyright law enforced," Hotaran said.

Romania, still on a U.S. Commerce Department "watch list" of countries with inadequate copyrights and high piracy rates, beefed up anti-piracy rules last year with a new copyright law, edging closer to Western practice.
Copyright breaches now carry jail terms of up to seven years and can trigger the loss of business licences.

Previous legislation had been built on "authors' rights" and tended to reside in the artists themselves, rather than protecting manufacturers of potentially copyright material. It also excluded information such as news.
